_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including associates that Allens, Inc. is complying with OSHA's
Process Safety Management Standards (called Process Safety Management or PSM), Title 29 Code of 
Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations 
(called RM Program), Title 40 CFR Part 68 to manage the risks involved with the storage, handling, and 
processing of hazardous chemicals.  In this way we promote overall plant, worker, and public safety.  
These programs enable our facility to minimize the occurrence and consequences of significant releases 
of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  
Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid
physical property damage.


Our safety programs are applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, 
handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals.  Any group of vessels which are interconnected and 
separate vessels which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release 
shall be considered a single process.  


Our safety programs show a commitment to safety and implimentation of safe procedures to minimize 
accidents as they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, 
or equipment.  These programs are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to
and accepted by all associates at the facility.


Description


This facility is a frozen vegetable processing plant, which produces bulk frozen peas, various green beans,
cob corn, cut corn and carrots.  These vegetables are locally grown and transported to our facility for 
processing. The refrigeration process for freezing these vegatables involves the use of Anhydrous Ammonia.  


The ammonia refrigeration process at this facility consists of various pumps, compressors, and condensers
that are used to change t

he state of ammonia from a gas to a liquid in a closed system. The system 
operation is very similar to the operation of a household refrigerator.  We have three independent systems, 
with the largest system containing 40,393 pounds.  The other two systems contain 28,636 pounds and 4,286
pounds respectfully. The system that contains 4,286 pounds operates our cold storage warehouse. 


Prevention Program

The general accident prevention program and ammonia-specific prevention steps were developed as 
required and they comply with OSHA PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA RM Program regulations
in 40 CFR Part 68.  The key prevention steps at the facility consist of the following:


- Process Safety Information
- Process Hazard Analysis
- Standard Operating Procedures
- Training
- Management of Change
- Pre-startup Safety Review
- Compliance Audits
- Incident Investigation
- Employee Participation
- Hot Work Permit
- Contractor Qualifications
- Comprehensive Yearly Maintenance Program
- Ammonia Detection System


Worst Case Scenario Update:

In the update of the worst case scenario we used the ALOHA program supplied by Genesee County Emergency Management. Based on the ALOHA program, Stability Class F was not compatable with any of the scenarios run. Stability class B matched with the conditions entered.




Five Year Accident History

There have been no releases of ammonia to report over the past five years, that have resulted in a major or
minor injury to an associate.


Emergency Response Program

Bergens' emergency response program is based on the OSHA requirements for Emergency Action 
Plans (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and HAZWOPER (29 CFR .120)  We have trained associates for 
emergency response and maintain a written emergency response plan.  Our associates receive refresher
training and physicals annually, paid for by the company. This plan is coordinated with the 
Genesee County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Bergen Fire Department.  We 
co

nduct annual drills for implementation of the emergency response plan at the facility with participation 
of the LEPC and the fire dept.  These drills are evaluated and documented to meet the criteria of our 
Emergency Response Program.  


Planned changes to improve safety

The facility has purchased and installed a new ammonia detection system with 16 different ammonia detection
sensors located throughout the facility.
